TITLE: Creating an Awkward Array from Python Data Structures

SOURCE: https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward/blob/main/docs/getting-started/index.md#2025-04-21_snippet_2

```
    [{"x": 1.1, "y": [1]}, {"x": 2.2, "y": [1, 2]}, {"x": 3.3, "y": [1, 2, 3]}],
```

TITLE: Using Awkward Arrays with Numba JIT Compilation in Python
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to use Awkward Arrays within Numba JIT-compiled functions for improved performance. The example shows a function that sums the 'x' field of records in nested lists.
SOURCE: https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward/blob/main/docs/getting-started/index.md#2025-04-21_snippet_10

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import awkward as ak
import numpy as np
import numba as nb

example = ak.Array([
    [{"x": 1.1, "y": [1]}, {"x": 2.2, "y": [1, 2]}, {"x": 3.3, "y": [1, 2, 3]}],
    [],
    [{"x": 4.4, "y": [1, 2, 3, 4]}, {"x": 5.5, "y": [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]}]
])

@nb.jit
def sum_over_x(array):
    output = np.zeros(len(array))
    for i, list_of_records in enumerate(array):
        for record in list_of_records:
            output[i] += record.x
    return output

sum_over_x(example)
```

TITLE: Using Nested Cartesian Product for Per-Bunny Analysis in Python
DESCRIPTION: Applies ak.cartesian with nested=True to create a structure where each bunny is paired with all foxes in its yard. This allows for per-bunny analysis using reducers like ak.any.
SOURCE: https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward/blob/main/docs/user-guide/how-to-combinatorics-best-match.md#2025-04-21_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
pair_bunnies, pair_foxes = ak.unzip(ak.cartesian([bunnies, foxes], nested=True))

distances = np.sqrt((pair_bunnies.x - pair_foxes.x)**2 + (pair_bunnies.y - pair_foxes.y)**2)
eaten = (distances < 1)

bunny_eaten = ak.any(eaten, axis=-1)
bunnies[~bunny_eaten]
```

TITLE: Building Records Using ArrayBuilder with Numba JIT
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates using ak.ArrayBuilder within JIT-compiled functions to build records with 'x' and 'y' fields. Shows how to create individual records and combine them into an array using builder.snapshot().
SOURCE: https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward/blob/main/docs/user-guide/how-to-create-records.md#2025-04-21_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@nb.jit
def append_record(builder, i):
    builder.begin_record()
    builder.field("x").append(i)
    builder.field("y").append(i * 1.1)
    builder.end_record()


@nb.jit
def example(builder):
    append_record(builder, 1)
    append_record(builder, 2)
    append_record(builder, 3)
    return builder


builder = example(ak.ArrayBuilder())

array = builder.snapshot()
array
```

TITLE: Finding Values with Numba-compiled Functions
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to write and use Numba-compiled functions to search through Awkward Arrays and return indices of specific values.
SOURCE: https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward/blob/main/docs/user-guide/how-to-use-in-numba-features.md#2025-04-21_snippet_1

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@nb.jit
def first_array(array):
    for i, list_of_numbers in enumerate(array):
        for x in list_of_numbers:
            if x == 3.3:
                return i

@nb.jit
def second_array(array):
    for i, list_of_records in enumerate(array):
        for record in list_of_records:
            if record.x == 3.3:
                return i

@nb.jit
def where_is_3_point_3(a, b):
    return first_array(a), second_array(b)
```

```
import uproot
import awkward as ak
import numpy as np

file = uproot.open("https://github.com/jpivarski-talks/2023-12-18-hsf-india-tutorial-bhubaneswar/raw/main/data/SMHiggsToZZTo4L.root")

    "pt": arrays["Muon_pt"],
    "eta": arrays["Muon_eta"],
    "phi": arrays["Muon_phi"],
    "charge": arrays["Muon_charge"],
})
```

TITLE: Point Mixin Class Implementation
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use mixin decorators to implement a Point class with custom behaviors for equality, absolute value, and addition.
SOURCE: https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward/blob/main/docs/reference/ak.behavior.md#2025-04-21_snippet_8

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@ak.mixin_class(ak.behavior)
class Point:
    def distance(self, other):
        return np.sqrt((self.x - other.x) ** 2 + (self.y - other.y) ** 2)

    @ak.mixin_class_method(np.equal, {"Point"})
    def point_equal(self, other):
        return np.logical_and(self.x == other.x, self.y == other.y)

    @ak.mixin_class_method(np.abs)
    def point_abs(self):
        return np.sqrt(self.x ** 2 + self.y ** 2)
```

TITLE: Creating Awkward Array using Numba with Unflattening
DESCRIPTION: This example shows how to use Numba JIT compilation to create flat data and counts arrays, which are then unflattened to create an Awkward Array.

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@nb.jit
def append_list(i, data, j, counts, start, stop):
    for x in range(start, stop):
        data[i] = x
        i += 1
    counts[j] = stop - start
    j += 1
    return i, j

@nb.jit
def example():
    data = np.empty(5, np.int64)
    counts = np.empty(3, np.int64)
    i, j = 0, 0
    i, j = append_list(i, data, j, counts, 1, 4)
    i, j = append_list(i, data, j, counts, 999, 999)
    i, j = append_list(i, data, j, counts, 4, 6)
    return data, counts

data, counts = example()

array = ak.unflatten(data, counts)
array
```

TITLE: Defining a CUDA Kernel for Awkward Array Processing
DESCRIPTION: This snippet defines a CUDA kernel function that processes Awkward Arrays. It calculates the sum of elements for each sub-array in the input array. The function is decorated with @numba.cuda.jit and uses the ak.numba.cuda extension.
SOURCE: https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward/blob/main/docs/user-guide/how-to-use-in-numba-cuda.ipynb#2025-04-21_snippet_2

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@numba.cuda.jit(extensions=[ak.numba.cuda])
def path_length(out, array):
    tid = numba.cuda.grid(1)
    if tid < len(array):
        out[tid] = 0
        for i, x in enumerate(array[tid]):
            out[tid] += x
```

TITLE: Creating Named Records with Customized Behavior in Awkward Array
DESCRIPTION: This code snippet demonstrates how to create named records and customize their behavior using the ak.behavior registry, including custom __repr__, methods, and NumPy function overloading.
SOURCE: https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward/blob/main/docs/user-guide/how-to-create-records.md#2025-04-21_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
class XYZRecord(ak.Record):
    def __repr__(self):
        return f"(X={self.x}:Y={self.y})"

class XYZArray(ak.Array):
    def diff(self):
        return abs(self.x - self.y)

ak.behavior["XYZ"] = XYZRecord
ak.behavior["*", "XYZ"] = XYZArray
ak.behavior["__typestr__", "XYZ"] = "XYZ"
ak.behavior[np.sqrt, "XYZ"] = lambda xyz: np.sqrt(xyz.x)

array = ak.Array(
    [
        {"x": 1, "y": 1.1},
        {"x": 2, "y": 2.2},
        {"x": 3, "y": 3.3},
        {"x": 4, "y": 4.4},
        {"x": 5, "y": 5.5},
    ],
    with_name="XYZ"
)
array
```

TITLE: Numba Boolean Mask Generation
DESCRIPTION: Creates a boolean mask for filtering arrays based on sum calculations using Numba
SOURCE: https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward/blob/main/docs/user-guide/how-to-use-in-numba-intro.md#2025-04-21_snippet_4

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@nb.jit
def sum_of_y_is_more_than_10(array):
    out = np.zeros(len(array), dtype=np.bool_)

    for i, list_of_records in enumerate(array):
        total = 0
        for record in list_of_records:
            for y in record.y:
                total += y
        if total > 10:
            out[i] = True

    return out
```

TITLE: Numba JIT-compiled Sum Function
DESCRIPTION: Implements a faster sum calculation using Numba's JIT compilation with explicit loops
SOURCE: https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward/blob/main/docs/user-guide/how-to-use-in-numba-intro.md#2025-04-21_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@nb.jit
def sum_of_y(array):
    out = np.zeros(len(array), dtype=np.int64)

    for i, list_of_records in enumerate(array):
        for record in list_of_records:
            for y in record.y:
                out[i] += y

    return out
```

TITLE: Implementing Multiplication with Scalar Values
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates implementing commutative multiplication between points and scalar values using numbers.Real type.
SOURCE: https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward/blob/main/docs/reference/ak.behavior.md#2025-04-21_snippet_5

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
import numbers
def point_lmult(point, scalar):
    return ak.Array({"x": point.x * scalar, "y": point.y * scalar})

def point_rmult(scalar, point):
    return point_lmult(point, scalar)

ak.behavior[np.multiply, "point", numbers.Real] = point_lmult
ak.behavior[np.multiply, numbers.Real, "point"] = point_rmult
```

TITLE: Reading Packed Multi-Bit Integers in AwkwardForth
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to read a sequence of arbitrary bit-width integers (3-bit in this example) that don't align with byte boundaries, demonstrating bit-packing capabilities.
SOURCE: https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward/blob/main/docs/reference/awkwardforth.rst#2025-04-21_snippet_43

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
>>> vm = ForthMachine32("""
... input x
... output y int32
... 
... .\" begin: \" x pos . cr   \\ show the starting input position
... 
... 8 x #3bit-> y
... 
... .\" end:   \" x pos . cr   \\ show the position after reading 8 3-bit integers
... .\" total: \" x len . cr   \\ show the total length of the input
... """)
>>> vm.run({"x": np.array([0b_000_001_010_011_100_101_110_111], np.uint32)})
begin: 0 
end:   3 
total: 4 
>>> np.asarray(vm["y"])
array([7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, 0], dtype=int32)
```

TITLE: WeightedPoint Mixin Class Implementation
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates inheritance of Point behaviors in a WeightedPoint class with custom equality and weighted addition operations.
SOURCE: https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward/blob/main/docs/reference/ak.behavior.md#2025-04-21_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: python
CODE:
```
@ak.mixin_class(ak.behavior)
class WeightedPoint(Point):
    @ak.mixin_class_method(np.equal, {"WeightedPoint"})
    def weighted_equal(self, other):
        return np.logical_and(self.point_equal(other), self.weight == other.weight)

    @ak.mixin_class_method(np.add, {"WeightedPoint"})
    def weighted_add(self, other):
        sumw = self.weight + other.weight
        return ak.zip(
            {
                "x": (self.x * self.weight + other.x * other.weight) / sumw,
                "y": (self.y * self.weight + other.y * other.weight) / sumw,
                "weight": sumw,
            },
            with_name="WeightedPoint",
        )
```

```
    aform.append('{{"class": "RegularArray","content": {{"class": "NumpyArray","primitive": "uint8","form_key": "node{}"}},"size": {},"form_key": "node{}"}},\n'.format(count+1,file["size"],count))
    strr.append("\n"+"    "*ind+"lenn = {}".format(file["size"]))
    strr.append("\n"+"    "*ind+"print(fields[pos:pos+lenn].tobytes())")
    strr.append("\n"+"    "*ind+"for i in range(lenn):")
    strr.append("\n"+"    "*(ind+1)+"con['part0-node{}-data'].append(np.uint8(fields[i]))".format(count+1))
    strr.append("\n"+"    "*ind+"pos = pos+lenn")
    return aform,strr,count+1,dec
```

TITLE: C++ to Python Data Transfer
DESCRIPTION: Function to transfer builder data to Python using pybind11
SOURCE: https://github.com/scikit-hep/awkward/blob/main/docs/user-guide/how-to-use-header-only-layoutbuilder.md#2025-04-21_snippet_9

LANGUAGE: cpp
CODE:
```
template <typename T>
py::object snapshot_builder(const T& builder)
{
    std::map<std::string, size_t> names_nbytes = {};
    builder.buffer_nbytes(names_nbytes);

    std::map<std::string, void*> buffers = {};
    for(auto it : names_nbytes) {
        uint8_t* ptr = new uint8_t[it.second];
        buffers[it.first] = (void*)ptr;
    }

    builder.to_buffers(buffers);
    auto from_buffers = py::module::import("awkward").attr("from_buffers");

    py::dict container;
    for (auto it: buffers) {
        py::capsule free_when_done(it.second, [](void *data) {
            uint8_t* dataPtr = reinterpret_cast<uint8_t*>(data);
            delete[] dataPtr;
        });

        uint8_t* data = reinterpret_cast<uint8_t*>(it.second);
        container[py::str(it.first)] = py::array_t<uint8_t>(
            {names_nbytes[it.first]},
            {sizeof(uint8_t)},
            data,
            free_when_done
        );
    }
    return from_buffers(builder.form(), builder.length(), container);
}
```

TITLE: Building CPU Kernels and libawkward for Awkward C++
DESCRIPTION: Configures the build process for CPU kernels and the main libawkward library. Sets compiler flags, visibility settings, and links dependencies.

```
  awkward-cpu-kernels
  PROPERTIES CXX_VISIBILITY_PRESET hidden

             CXX_EXTENSIONS NO)

    awkward

            -Wweak-vtables
            -Wshorten-64-to-32
            -Wsign-compare
            -Wsign-conversion
            -Wshift-sign-overflow
            -Wreorder
            -Wrange-loop-analysis
            -Wconversion
            -Wunused)
endif()
target_link_libraries(awkward PUBLIC awkward-parent)
```
